meanings.definition: To make something impure or inferior.
meanings.sent1: He tried to bastardise the cake by adding too much salt.
meanings.sent2: The counterfeit products were created to bastardise the market.
meanings.sent3: The prankster decided to bastardise the recipe by swapping sugar with salt.
meanings.sent4: The forger managed to bastardise the painting, fooling many art experts.
meanings.sent5: The virus managed to bastardise the computer system, causing chaos.

meanings.definition: To change something in a way that makes it less genuine or authentic.
meanings.sent1: The fake designer bags were made to bastardise the original brand.
meanings.sent2: The unreliable sources of information can easily bastardise the truth.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked that adding pineapple to pizza would bastardise the Italian cuisine.
meanings.sent4: The gossip spread quickly, threatening to bastardise the reputation of the celebrity.
meanings.sent5: The alterations to the historical document would bastardise its significance.
